Description: Scarab in Egyptian blue, probably mould-made; underside decorated with image of a seated winged lion (or griffin?) facing right with unidentified element to right(possibly a nefer sign) and human figure to left; motif probably incised.
Curator's comments: Scarab not yet located, published by Petrie (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 23). Winged mythological creatures are a very popular motif in the Scarab Factory (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). This Egyptian Blue scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, especially in Carthage, Kerkouan, Sicily and Gibraltar, but also in Greece, Cyprus and Rhodes (Gorton 1996, 118-121, type XXXIII, subtype A25-41, see especially A37 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Sign to left is very probably a nefer sign, as on the scarab published by Petrie as no 22, adjacent to it on Pl. XXXVII.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 23)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 119, Type XXXIII A37)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.14) (phase 3)
